entry.title: Building Intelligent Enterprise by Adopting AI, Design Thinking, and Enterprise Architecture
entry.content:
AI holds immense potential to transform enterprises and businesses, with a projected global market size of $190 billion by 2025 according to Statista. However, according to a report by McKinsey, only 8% of enterprises have successfully scaled AI initiatives across their departments, processes, and business lines. This highlights the need for a structured framework and ways of working that can guide enterprises in integrating AI effectively. 

Enterprise Design Thinking is a human-centered mindset and approach to innovation that emphasizes empathy, creativity, and iterative prototyping. By applying Enterprise Design Thinking principles, enterprises can better understand the needs and expectations of their customers and employees, internal and external stakeholders, leading the development of more impactful AI solutions.

Furthermore, Enterprise Architecture provides a blueprint for aligning an enterprise's business and IT strategies. By incorporating AI into their enterprise architecture frameworks, enterprises can ensure that AI initiatives are closely aligned with their overall business objectives. According to a survey by Deloitte, 69% of enterprise architecture programs have started incorporating AI into their strategies. 

To effectively integrate AI, Enteprise Design Thinking, and Enterprise Architecture, enterprises can follow a light four-step framework:

  1. Define and Frame the Problem: Begin by identifying a specific enterprise/business challenge or opportunity that could benefit from AI. Use Design Thinking principles to empathize with stakeholders and gain a deep understanding of the problem. Then using problem framing to frame the right problems to solve within enterprise.
  2. Design the Solution: Use Enterprise Design Thinking to ideate and prototype potential AI solutions. Focus on creating solutions that are user-centric and align with the enterprise's overall strategy. 
  3. Integrate AI into Enterprise Architecture: Develope a detailed adaptive strategy and plan for integrating the AI solution into the enterprise's existing architecture. Consider factors such as data integration, security, and scalability.
  4. Monitor and Iterate: Continuosly monitor the performance of the AI solution and gather feedback from users. Use this feedback loop to iterate and improve the solution over time. 

By following this light framework, enterprises can ensure that their AI initiatives are not only technically sound but also deliver tangible business value. By combining the power of AI, Design Thinking, and Enterprise Architecture, enterprises can build intelligent enterprises that become more agile, innovative, and stakeholder-focuses.

entry.title: Creating a story with Dynamic Version & Date Combinations
entry.content:
Introduction

 

Designing a story in SAP Analytics Cloud can be easy and straightforward with many features to create calculations, columns, styles. The drag and drop functionality helps users create reports with different layouts of various complexity . Optimized story design is also helpful to create advanced stories and reporting layouts using JavaScript to achieve complex functionality and user interactions.

When designing any report or input form, if the layout contains Version and Date dimensions, adding multiple members of versions and Months or Years can result in a Layout that has columns with all the combinations of the members. For example, if the selections contain Actual, Budget for Version and Date contains years 2024 and 2025, the report will have 4 columns. Even though the intention is to show only 2 columns with combinations of [Actual, 2023] and [Budget, 2024], the final report contains all 4 combinations.

There are ways in which we can show only valid/required combinations, for example hiding unwanted columns or suppress columns with no data or using Advanced Filters. But these approaches are not dynamic. Every time there is a change in Version or Date, the columns need to be adjusted manually. It might also create many static reports to achieve different combination reports.

The alternate approach is to create dynamic reports is using Optimized story design using JavaScript and SAC Advanced Script API to show columns with only valid/required combinations. This blog provides required design and logic required for interactions and filtering.
 

Step 1 - Creating Design Elements

The design of the dashboard uses dropdown menus instead of filters define within Story. The user can select required Dimension members from dropdown and on submit the selections will be sent to the table filters dynamically. We will use story calculations to create required combinations and further use SAC Analytics designer and API to update dimension filters with required combinations.

Step 1-a
  • Create a New story using Optimized Story design.
  • Add 4 Dropdown menus ( Insert -> Filters/Controls -> Dropdown). 2 for Actual / 2023 and 2 for Budget/ 2024. 
  • Dropdown names dd_fy1, dd_fy2 for years & dd_cat1, dd_cat2 for versions. 
  • Add 1 submit button ( Insert -> Button )
  • Button name : btn_1
  • Add 1 Table and connect to model. Add necessary filters. ( We need to update the filters at a later stage to show necessary columns)
  • Table Name: table_1

 

Step 1-b
Once the dropdown menus are added, from the script edit page, add the values required for the dropdown menus. Year dropdown has values as Years and Version dropdown has values as Version names. Below images show the options used for each dropdown.
 
 
 
 
The final result will be 4 dropdown menus with values and a Submit button. 
 

 

Step 2 - Logic 

Till now we have added design elements in the Story. Now we need to add logic to capture the values selected from dropdown menus and send them story filters.

logic to be added on btn_1 onClick function

The logic has 3 main parts. 

  1. extract the selections used from the dropdown menus and pass them to variables and arrays
  2. create valid combinations by combining Version + year values and push into array
  3. Filter the Version, Year and Valid Combinations values on the table

 

 

 

 

//extract selected versions into variables 
var version1 = dd_cat1.getSelectedKey(); 
var version2 = dd_cat2.getSelectedKey(); 

// append public to variables created above 
var col1_version = "public."+version1; 
var col2_version = "public."+version2; 

//extract selected versions into variables 
var col1_fy = dd_fy1.getSelectedKey(); 
var col2_fy = dd_fy2.getSelectedKey(); 

// save table into variable 
var ds_table1 = table_1.getDataSource(); 

// get dimension names into variables. Note the order of dimensions added in columns. 
// 0 is version, 1 is for year 
var version_col =table_1.getDimensionsOnColumns()[0]; 
var fy_col =table_1.getDimensionsOnColumns()[1]; 

// create an empty array to hold version values and add the version variables created above 
var version_cols_values = ArrayUtils.create(Type.string); 
version_cols_values.push(col1_version); 
version_cols_values.push(col2_version); 

// create an empty array to hold year values and add the year variables created above 
var fy_cols_values = ArrayUtils.create(Type.string); 
fy_cols_values.push(col1_fy); 
fy_cols_values.push(col2_fy); 

// create an empty array for valid combinations 
// for example Actual2023, Budget2024 
var valid_comb = ArrayUtils.create(Type.string); 
valid_comb.push(version1+col1_fy); 
valid_comb.push(version2+col2_fy); 


// set the 3 dimension filters for Version, Date, valid_combinations on the table 
ds_table1.setDimensionFilter(version_col,version_cols_values); 
ds_table1.setDimensionFilter(fy_col,fy_cols_values); 

ds_table1.setDimensionFilter(table_1.getDimensionsOnColumns()[2],valid_comb);

 

 

 

 

Step 3 - Story

The JavaScript logic above filters the dimension values for Version and Time , Fiscal Year values. But filtering alone on Version and Time still result in additional columns which are not required. So we need to create an additional calculated dimension call "valid_combinations" to identify the required columns and filter them during the runtime.

 

 

Below is the code used for creating the calculated dimension. The code uses Version and Fiscal Year to derive the all the possible combinations of columns. One can add many versions, years and create all past and future values possible.

entry.title: SAP for Me: Involving customer feedback
entry.content:
In today's 24/7 business environment, time is an organization's most valuable resource, especially when dealing with outages that require immediate resolution to keep systems and applications running. To streamline decision-making during such events and reduce solution time, SAP collaborated with four customers to develop a new Outage Experience within SAP for Me, the personalized central entry point providing quick access to SAP products, support, and services.

 

Actively involving customers

With the SAP Fiori Makers, SAP offers customer bootcamps to design solutions for specific use cases. Recently, adidas, Boehringer Ingelheim, Endress+Hauser, and BASF participated in a four-day bootcamp, gaining valuable insights into SAP Fiori and their end-user needs.

Customer Sascha Dörner, Head of SAP Cross Applications at Boehringer Ingelheim, highlights the success of these bootcamps and his user experience in a positive vein: “We were extremely surprised on how well the finished solution met our expectations and requirements. The methodology and implementation of the bootcamp deserves a special mention, as both played a key role in ensuring that the solution includes end-user feedback and brings real added value. I came to the workshop with a precise idea of the problem and how it could be solved. The professional approach opened further perspectives and dimensions for us, which ultimately led to an even better result.”

Supporting this view, Judith Schneider, UX Designer and SAP Fiori expert, describes the bootcamp setup and goals stating, “We include customers and users from the very beginning of our development journey. In doing so, new ideas flow and areas for improvement can be identified early on. Following this design-led development approach, our customers help shape the user experience according to their expectations.”

 

SAP’s design-led development process guarantees a solid and consistent user experience that addresses the needs of end-users across all lines of business, tasks, and devices.

To ensure that the outage solution will meet end-user needs, the main persona—an IT admin—has been defined and SAP’s Scenes tool has been used to visualize the user story during an outage. This collaborative process identified additional personas, key notifications, and communication channels, leading participants to create low-fi mockups and ultimately translate the use case into SAP Fiori for a high-fi mockup and a future software prototype.

With Scenes, storyboards about products and services can be created fast, collaboratively, and iteratively.

Benefits of the new Outage Experience in SAP for Me

The new Outage Experience in SAP for Me ensures that users stay informed with real-time event handling across mobile apps and smartwatches. Nathalie Pardini, SAP Product Owner, emphasizes, “This innovative solution gives customers the ability to customize outage notifications according to their specific business needs. By targeting specific users, businesses can ensure that the right people receive important outage information in a timely manner. Thanks to the valuable input from our representative customers, this solution has been widely embraced since its launch and continues to gain momentum.”

The new feature, Bundles, is a flexible grouping of cloud services and systems that offers three key benefits to SAP customers:

  • Customers can give intuitive names to Bundles and mark them with a business criticality, allowing for customized and prioritized notification management.
  • Notifications provide clear and accessible information about the specific parts of their business and processes affected by downtime, enabling customers to quickly understand the impact and take appropriate action.
  • Only relevant and impacted key users will be notified thanks to subscriptions on Bundles, ensuring that the right individuals receive timely and essential information. A notification history provides ongoing updates and post-incident summaries, complete with root cause analysis, helping prevent future outages.

Martin Buselmeier, Solution Architect Integration and Platform at Endress+Hauser, highlights the way this new solution meets their organization’s expectations: “Bundles are the perfect opportunity for us to group various SAP Business Technology Platform and SAP services that relate in various ways. By freely choosing the names, we can use Endress+Hauser's own terminology for recognition and quickly establish the context. Through the subscription, it is now also possible for us to automatically inform stakeholders outside SAP for Me, such as key users or project managers, about downtimes without having to involve an interpreter.”

The new Outage Experience now offers all the user-desired information to handle future outages most efficiently.

Optimizing products with user research – be part of it!

Engaging customers and end-users with their feedback early in the development of the Outage Experience was pivotal in creating a solution that genuinely met their needs. By gaining both a deep understanding of their pain points and needs, SAP successfully developed a product that resonated with users. As one end-user noted, "This is a very user-friendly and functional solution that truly helps customers adapt to specific scenarios or events."

This underscores the critical role user research plays in driving successful product development. In 2023, SAP introduced the SAP User Research Panel, a user research initiative that invites end-users to participate in remote research activities. They can share their product and design experiences, help shape SAP products to better align with their needs, while also offering them a preview of new features or products.


Make your voice heard! Join the SAP User Research Panel. Registration is unbinding and easy, taking part in research studies is convenient, taking ten to sixty minutes.

entry.title: Building a Sales Organizational Structure in SAP: A Bottom-Up Approach
entry.content:
In any organization, a well-structured sales hierarchy is key to managing operations efficiently. Instead of looking at it from the top down, let’s take a bottom-up approach, starting from the execution teams and working our way up to strategic decision-making.

 

1. Sales Group: The Frontline Sales Force

At the foundation of any sales structure is the Sales Group, which consists of the individuals responsible for selling products in their assigned regions. These teams interact directly with customers, generate sales, and ensure smooth order fulfillment.

Creation: Sales Group

  • Path: Enterprise Structure → Definition → Sales and Distribution → Maintain Sales Group

Assignment: Sales Group to Sales Office

  • Path: Enterprise Structure → Assignment → Sales and Distribution → Assign Sales Group to Sales Office

2. Sales Office: Managing Regional Operations

Each Sales Group reports to a Sales Office, which acts as the regional hub for sales activities. These offices oversee sales teams, provide support, and manage operational logistics.

For example:

  • The Singapore Sales Office oversees operations in South East Asia.
  • The Germany Sales Office handles sales for East Asia.

Creation: Sales Office

  • Path: Enterprise Structure → Definition → Sales and Distribution → Maintain Sales Office

Assignment: Sales Office to Sales Area

  • Path: Enterprise Structure → Assignment → Sales and Distribution → Assign Sales Office to Sales Areas

3. Sales Area: Defining Product, Channel, and Organization Alignment

Before products reach customers, they must be assigned to a Sales Area, which is a combination of three critical elements:

  1. Sales Organization (the business entity responsible for sales)
  2. Distribution Channel (the method of selling)
  3. Division (the type of product)

For example:

  • Sales Org: Food + Wholesale Channel + Carcass Division → This area focuses on selling raw food products through wholesale distributors.
  • Sales Org: Food + Retail Channel + Processed Division → This area manages processed food products sold directly to retail customers.

Each Sales Area determines pricing, customer contracts, and order management processes.

Assignment: Sales Area Setup

  • Path: Enterprise Structure → Assignment → Sales and Distribution → Set Up Sales Area

4. Division: Organizing Product Categories

A Division categorizes products based on how they are handled in the supply chain. The three divisions in this structure are:

  • Carcass → Raw, unprocessed goods.
  • Processed → Packaged and ready-to-consume products.
  • Live Stock → Direct sale of live animals.

Divisions ensure that sales teams know which products they are responsible for and how they should be distributed.

Creation: Division

  • Path: Enterprise Structure → Definition → Logistics – General → Define, Copy, Delete, Check Division (T-code: OVXB)

Assignment: Division to Sales Organization

  • Path: Enterprise Structure → Assignment → Sales and Distribution → Assign Division to Sales Organization

5. Distribution Channel: Delivering Products to Customers

Once products are categorized, they need a Distribution Channel to reach customers. The company uses three primary channels:

  • Wholesale → Bulk selling to large-scale buyers.
  • Retail → Direct sales to consumers through stores or e-commerce.
  • Distributor → Third-party partners who handle sales and distribution.

Each channel serves a unique market and requires different sales strategies.

Creation: Distribution Channel

  • Path: Enterprise Structure → Definition → Sales and Distribution → Define, Copy, Delete, Check Distribution Channel (T-code: OVXI)

Assignment: Distribution Channel to Sales Organization

  • Path: Enterprise Structure → Assignment → Sales and Distribution → Assign Distribution Channel to Sales Organization

6. Sales Organization: The Strategic Backbone

At the highest level, we have the Sales Organization, which oversees all sales functions. In this structure, there are two main Sales Organizations:

  • Food
  • Packaging

These organizations define high-level strategies, pricing policies, and overall business goals for their respective industries.

Creation: Sales Organization

  • Path: Enterprise Structure → Definition → Sales and Distribution → Define, Copy, Delete, Check Sales Organization (T-code: OVX5)

Conclusion

By building the SAP Sales Organizational Structure from the ground up, we can see how each layer supports the one above it. The Sales Groups execute the strategy, the Sales Offices manage regions, the Sales Areas define product-market alignment, and the Sales Organization oversees the entire operation.

This bottom-up approach highlights the importance of each role in ensuring seamless sales execution, efficient distribution, and strong market presence.

entry.title: Energy supplier badenova transforms work order coordination with SAP Fiori Makers boot camp
entry.content:
In September 2024, SAP customer and German energy supplier badenova embarked on a transformative journey to streamline its work order coordination processes. To better manage the persistent operational challenges around customer requests, its subsidiary badenovaNETZE joined the SAP Fiori Makers program for an intensive, hands-on boot camp in Freiburg, Germany.

The boot camp focused on addressing and analyzing the real challenges faced by the company’s work order coordinators to optimize their daily work experience and routines.

The challenge: A fragmented, manual process

Before the boot camp, badenovaNETZE’s work order coordination was a fragmented mix of tools and processes. Coordinators were juggling SAP software, custom programs from SmartService Solutions, and basic applications like Word and Excel to complete their tasks. The status quo resulted in a couple of challenges to address and optimize:

  • Improve user experience: The existing interface was difficult to navigate, leading to user frustration and reduced productivity.
  • Avoid manual processes: Coordinators had to both transfer information across multiple systems and update data manually, making routine tasks time-consuming and prone to errors.
  • Reduce error rate: The repetitive, manual tasks increased the risk of data entry errors, causing delays and additional workload.
  • Increase transparency: With limited visibility into work order statuses, coordinators spent a lot of time tracking down information and monitoring progress.

The solution: A hands-on transformation

The company participated in a four-day SAP Fiori Makers boot camp, bringing together customer end users, IT teams, and partners. The focus of the boot camp was to improve the usability of the work order cockpit by transitioning from manual tasks and workarounds to an SAP app prototype as a tangible starting point. It aimed at implementing process automation, incorporating dashboards, enhancing the user experience, and reducing error rates.

The boot camp provided badenovaNETZE with the tools and an open, agile workshop format needed to tackle these challenges. Based on this close collaboration with the company’s coordinators, the SAP team developed customized solutions that streamlined processes and the final outcome. “The beauty of our boot camps is that we get to know and truly understand the challenges of our end users,” SAP UX Designer Christina Salwitzek summarizes. “Together with the end user and from the beginning, we designed and developed a more efficient solution for this complex workflow.”

Preview of a work order screen at badenova (menu items are in German)

 

The objectives

badenovaNETZE faces operational challenges when managing numerous customer requests in metering, including meter replacement, installation, and removal. Together, the teams set ambitious yet achievable objectives to ensure long-term success. Operational readiness by 2025 was the top priority, with a clear goal of transitioning to an optimized, future-proof system in the first half of the new year.

To support this transition, the boot camp helped increase SAP technology knowledge and development skills within the badenovaNETZE team. The team is now prepared to maintain, adapt, and expand the new solution as their needs evolve. “What surprised me the most is that we actually made such good progress together and that everybody was able to contribute something,” says Paulina Deren, order coordination advisor at badenovaNETZE.

Finally, the team established a prioritized road map—a clear, phased approach designed to guide the customer through each stage of the transformation, enabling a smooth journey from concept to realization. The SAP Fiori Makers team included three UX designers, an SAP Fiori elements front-end developer who brought the visual designs to life, and a backend developer specializing in the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model framework to help ensure robust, scalable functionality. The team was guided by Andreas Spahn, principal technology & innovation manager from the SAP Services team, who moderated the boot camp and facilitated collaboration. “What makes SAP Fiori Makers so special is that we have one problem statement and we have one team to analyze today’s problem with the end user and solve it,” he says. “This involves experts from technology, design, and development.”

The SAP design system is ready to usher in the next evolution of enterprise software
Learn more

The experience

A core element was the creation of a user-centric and future-focused design for a new work order cockpit. The team used design thinking techniques in combination with the capabilities of SAP Fiori, SAP Fiori elements, and SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP) to get started. Being one of Germany’s largest regional suppliers of electricity, natural gas, heat energy, and water, badenova already used SAP BTP for integration scenarios and started using it for application development with this project.

For its intuitive, streamlined interface, the team conducted a thorough feasibility assessment to validate the proposed solution’s technical and operational viability. They then rapidly co-created and prototyped solutions in close collaboration with actual users.

The derived prototype not only simplified complex workflows but also significantly reduced manual tasks, minimized errors, and eliminated data silos. By centralizing all relevant information into a unified system, the team delivered a seamless user experience, initiating the groundwork necessary for full deployment.

The result garnered positive feedback from participants, reflecting the practicality and innovation of the solution. “Most impressive to me was the headway made,” Daniel Oberle, business architect at badenovaNETZE, says. “Without the SAP Fiori Makers boot camp, we would be looking at another half a year to get to where we are just now.”

Real user feedback

To ensure the solution truly resonated with its users, the team conducted three on-site, moderated usability tests using a Figma prototype. Each session included two notetakers capturing live feedback directly within Figma, allowing for immediate insights and adjustments. The initial user stories were visualized using SAP’s Scenes storytelling tool, which enabled the team to quickly create collaborative, visual narratives without the need for drawing skills. These early concepts were then refined with SAP Fiori design stencils in Figma, streamlining the transition from rough ideas to polished prototypes.

The involvement of SAP users during the boot camp was instrumental, providing real-time evaluation through cognitive walkthroughs. “If the user experience fits, employees are happy and enjoy using the software,” Teresa Mayer, UX designer at SAP, says. This hands-on, iterative process helped ensure the final design aligned closely with user expectations and needs.

This example underscores the critical role user research plays in driving successful, error-free, and beneficial product development. To strengthen its user feedback approach even further, SAP introduced the SAP User Research Panel program. This initiative invites users to participate in remote research activities, allowing SAP’s product teams to get feedback along the product life cycle. Users can share their product and design experiences to help shape SAP products to better align with their needs while also getting a preview of new features or products.

 

Conclusion

The SAP Fiori Makers boot camp proved to be a pivotal step in badenovaNETZE’s digital transformation journey. By combining cutting-edge SAP technologies with a user-centric design approach, the team not only tackled complex operational challenges but also delivered a solution that significantly enhances efficiency and user satisfaction. The rapid progress made during the boot camp—cutting down development time by six months and projecting savings of 115 working days per year—underscores the power of collaboration and innovation.

With the project already underway and goals for 2025 set, badenovaNETZE is well-positioned to continue refining and optimizing processes with an even more engaged and satisfied workforce.

🔍 Why Focus on AI in Serialization?

SAP Serialization solutions provide rich, structured data - batch numbers, production line metrics, event histories, and global traceability records. This makes them an ideal foundation for AI-driven innovation.

During the workshop, we explored several high-impact use cases, including:

  • Predictive Exception Management – Flagging anomalies in serial number generation, shipping delays, or partner reporting issues.

We’re exploring pilot initiatives, both focused on intelligent exception handling and traceability assistants. The goal is to improve operational agility and compliance confidence while laying the foundation for more advanced AI capabilities.

entry.title: Unlocking the Potential of Templates in SAP Build Store: A UX-Led Transformation
entry.content:
In early 2024, we discovered something surprising.
The average user spent just 1 minute and 14 seconds in the SAP Build Store. Even more striking: nearly 60% of users left within 15 seconds.

We had invested in pre-designed, ready-to-use solutions, what we call Templates, to accelerate project creation, reduce repetitive tasks, and improve efficiency across SAP Build. But the data told us something else: the feature was practically invisible.

The challenge: our locked treasure

Why was engagement so low? Our research revealed a few key reasons:

  • Terminology like “Store” and “Ready to Use” was confusing
  • The design was outdated and not aligned with SAP’s Fiori guidelines
  • Navigation was weak, leaving users without clear entry points
  • Most users only discovered the feature via a lobby shortcut. Without it, usage dropped dramatically

We had a powerful capability, but no visibility.

The original design: outdated, unclear, and often overlooked

 

Strategic context and research

This redesign was not done in isolation. It aligned with the SAP Build 2025 strategy, which emphasizes predefined processes and best practices to accelerate time to value.

We also reviewed how similar solutions in the market are positioned. A common theme was the strong emphasis on clarity and discoverability, which reinforced the importance of making SAP’s Templates more visible and actionable

 

The big idea: make Templates impossible to ignore

Our guiding principle was simple: Visibility, Clarity, Efficiency.
If users did not see it, they would not use it.

So the mission was twofold:

  1. Make Templates more discoverable, even without shortcuts
  2. Clarify their purpose so users could quickly understand and act

 

Transformation in action

We redesigned the experience with these goals in mind:

  • Consistency: A modern, structured UI aligned with SAP’s design language
  • Navigation: Clearer pathways and filters so users could find relevant templates more easily
  • Cards: A more engaging presentation with images, clearer actions, and hierarchy
  • Clarity: New status badges and improved copy to reduce confusion
  • Guidance: A new dialog to help users understand the difference between Pre-built and Sample templates
  • Terminology: We also introduced several naming changes to reduce confusion and better reflect the feature’s purpose, such as renaming “Store” to Templates, “Ready to Use” to Pre-built, and “Template” to Sample. These adjustments might look small, but they made the feature’s value clearer and easier to understand.

In short, the redesign turned Templates from a hidden corner into a visible, structured, and valuable part of the experience.

The redesigned templates: clearer hierarchy, modern visuals, and consistent actions..

 New Select Template dialog: shown when creating a template that supports both options, helping users choose between Pre-built and Sample with clearer guidance.

 

Testing with users

To validate the new approach, we ran two usability studies:

  • July 2024: with 6 internal SAP colleagues who used the Store daily
  • December 2024: with 5 SAP customers from Vodafone, AIRBUS, Merck, and Twinnings

The feedback was clear:

  • Users finally understood Templates
  • Many admitted they had not known the feature even existed before
  • Excitement grew as they realized Templates could meaningfully support their workflows

One participant summed it up:

“Positive step to move from Store to Template. The UI is much better from the old Store, it is awesome.”

 

The impact

This redesign has not yet been developed, and there is no confirmed timeline for implementation.
But the usability studies made one thing clear:

  • More visibility → more usage
  • More clarity → more efficiency
  • More usability → more business value

 

Key takeaways

  • Do not wait for permission. If something is broken, fix it
  • Business impact and usability go hand in hand
  • Visibility is everything. If users do not see it, they will not use it

This journey reminded me that some of the most impactful UX work is not about adding new features, but about unlocking the hidden value that already exists.

Have you faced a similar challenge in making an important feature more visible and usable? I’d love to hear how you approached it in your product.

⭐Bhayli & SAP: One Team, One Dream ⭐ Jai Seva — Victory in Service ⭐

As I look back on my final week in Jaipur, it feels like the culmination of not just a project, but of a journey of growth, collaboration, and shared purpose. What began four weeks ago with introductions, first impressions, and a steep learning curve has now come full circle with a clear strategy, a strong partnership, and lasting memories.

The SAP Social Sabbatical program brings together SAP employees from around the world to support innovative non-profits and social enterprises, helping them tackle real business challenges. Every organisation we’re working with are aligned with the UN Sustainable Development Goals, which makes this experience extremely meaningful, as it is fully aligned with some of my most treasured core values. This opportunity hits close to home — using the skills I’ve built over the years to support communities and businesses doing good in the world has always been a personal pursuit.

This last week marked an important milestone in our work with Bhayli — a women-led initiative that empowers artisans and supports the circular economy by transforming waste into beautiful, meaningful products. Bhayli empowers rural women in Rajasthan by training them to transform waste materials — like plastic bottles and beverage cans — into beautifully handwoven and handcrafted products. You can find more about Bhayli’s mission and vision in their website here and Instagram account here. Together with my SAP teammates Lucrecia Maphupha and Nidia Miguel in collaboration with Bhayli, we finalized a new Marketing and Sales phased business approach designed to capacitate Bhayli scale sustainably, strengthen its partnerships, and expand its impact.

Bhayli & SAP: One Team, One Dream

 

Design Thinking workshops

Building the Strategy

The fourth and last program week was all about bringing together the insights we had gathered over the previous three weeks. We refined the customer journeys, aligned on marketing opportunities, and worked through pricing strategies that would make sense both for Bhayli and its creative partners. It was an intense but rewarding process of distilling complex discussions into a clear, actionable roadmap.

One of the highlights of our collaboration with Bhayli was running a design thinking workshop with their team. The session brought together artisans, partners, and our sabbatical group to reimagine how Bhayli could expand its reach while staying true to its mission. Using hands-on exercises, we mapped customer needs, brainstormed new opportunities. What stood out most was the energy in the room: every idea, no matter how simple, sparked discussion, and every prototype carried a sense of pride and possibility. It was a powerful experience that not only generated practical insights for Bhayli’s growth but also built a deeper sense of connection and shared purpose among everyone involved.

There were moments of debate, brainstorming, and back-and-forth alignment — but that’s exactly what made the process so powerful. Each one of us brought different perspectives, shaped by our backgrounds and experiences, and those perspectives enriched the final outcome. It wasn’t just a project handed over — it was a true collaboration, built on trust and respect.

Bhayli's Business Growth Framework

Bhayli & SAP

 

The Final Presentation

Our program concluded with the final presentation, where we officially handed over the project deliverables. Standing together as a team, sharing our recommendations, and watching the Bhayli leadership nod with excitement and recognition was a moment of pride. It reminded me why programs like the SAP Social Sabbatical exist: to connect corporate skills with social impact, and to create bridges between business frameworks and grassroots innovation.

The presentation was more than a transfer of work — it was a celebration of the journey we had shared with Bhayli’s team, from long discussions over chai, to creative workshops shaping recycled materials, to aligning on business strategy that will help them grow their mission.

Final Presentation

Reflections on the Journey

As I reflect on these four weeks, what stands out most are not just the deliverables, but the people and experiences behind them. I think of the women artisans at Bhayli, whose creativity and resilience give life to products that carry both beauty and purpose. I think of the chaotic but vibrant streets of Jaipur — the honking symphony of traffic, the monsoon rains, the shared laughter over spicy meals. I think of my teammates, who became more than colleagues — they became friends, united by the shared challenge of making an impact.

This sabbatical has taught me that impact is rarely linear. It is messy, unpredictable, and sometimes overwhelming — but it is also deeply rewarding. By stepping out of our comfort zones, immersing ourselves in a new culture, and working alongside local partners, we not only helped build solutions but also learned to see the world through different lenses.

Taj Mahal visit

Gratitude

I am incredibly grateful to everyone who made this experience possible. To my fellow team members Lucrecia and Nidia— thank you for your dedication, your creativity, and your energy. To the Bhayli team, thank you for opening your doors, sharing your story, and allowing us to walk alongside you in this chapter of your journey. And to Pyxera Global, especially Shilpa Ahluwalia , Matrena Martin and Amisha Choudhary, thank you for organizing, guiding, and supporting us every step of the way. A big thanks to my extended SAP Team who shared this Journey with me: Evelyn Fromm, Oscar Fonque, Gisela Picaro, Daniel Fritsch, May Seet, Vera Volgina, Sebastian Lutz, Jackson Rogers, Carrie Barth and Vani Barg. Lastly I want to thank my manager Sam Forel for supporting me in this endeavor.

SAP Social Sabbatical Extended Team

Closing Thoughts - Key Takeaways

When I joined the SAP Social Sabbatical in Jaipur, I knew it would be a unique opportunity, but I didn’t realize just how much it would change me. My role was to work with Bhayli on creating a phased sales and marketing plan to capacitate their business scalability. On paper, it sounded like a familiar challenge. In reality, it pushed me far beyond my comfort zone and gave me lessons I’ll carry with me for years.

 The biggest change I experienced was building resilience, adaptability, and cultural awareness. Working in a completely new environment, with different ways of thinking and operating, forced me to let go of assumptions and really listen. It taught me to adapt quickly, stay resilient when things didn’t go as planned, and appreciate perspectives very different from my own.

 On a personal level, this opened my horizons. I discovered so much about Indian culture, the dedication of the artisans, and the sense of community around the work. I found myself becoming more empathetic, not only toward others but also in how I see the world — valuing patience, creativity, and the human stories behind every business.

SAP Social Sabbatical Extended Team

Professionally, the experience sharpened skills I thought I already knew. Leading design thinking workshops in this context showed me the power of collaboration and creativity when diverse voices are brought together. Managing scope and expectations in an environment so different from my usual work strengthened my ability to navigate ambiguity and lead with clarity.
As a former SAP CRM consultant focusing in marketing and sales business, it felt refreshing being able to use my knowledge in this context. In additional, my experience as Customer Success Manager in building relationships and retaining SAP Customers, also contributed to reflect on strategies and best practices that can be adopted by  Bhayli.

I also gained a deeper understanding of how businesses in India — and particularly artisan-driven businesses — operate, which gave me fresh insights into ecosystems far outside the corporate world. On top of that, having the chance to engage directly with C-level leaders from local organizations helped me grow my confidence in stakeholder management and strategic conversations.

 Looking back, Jaipur wasn’t just about contributing my expertise — it was about growing as a person and a professional. I came back with a stronger sense of resilience, an openness to new perspectives, and practical leadership skills that I apply every day as a Customer Success Manager. More than anything, it reminded me that real impact comes from empathy, collaboration, and the willingness to learn as much as you give.

As our sabbatical in Jaipur comes to an end, I carry with me not just professional learnings, but also personal reflections. This experience was a reminder that true change happens when people come together with openness, humility, and a shared vision for a better future.

Jaipur will always remain in my heart — not just as a place I visited, but as a community that welcomed me, challenged me, and inspired me. This is not the end, but the beginning of new ways of thinking about business, impact, and collaboration.Shaping a Hand Embossed Hosting Tray
